oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A broadside advertisement for the services of John T. Gordon’s carding machine and grain mill. An engraving of the carding machine is shown at the top of the broadside.

The majority of farming families hired the services of mills to convert their grains to flour and meal. While water-powered mills were more common and efficient, other milling machines were mobile contraptions powered by oxen or other livestock. Farmers usually paid for the services with services and goods as opposed to cash.
